summary: Email chain between attorneys and a U.S. Attorney's office regarding compliance with a grand jury subpoena served on Boies Schiller Flexner LLP for discovery materials in the case Giuffre v. Maxwell (15 Civ. 7433). The correspondence discusses document production logistics, indexing, and the scope of the subpoena, which is limited to that specific case and not others like Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein.

persons.context: Handles transmission of secured documents via ShareFile and acts as a point of contact for technical access issues related to the subpoenaed materials.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena Served
events.description: A grand jury subpoena was served on Boies Schiller Flexner LLP in connection with the case Giuffre v. Maxwell.

events.title: Document Production Rollout
events.description: Sigrid McCawley indicates ongoing rollout of documents in response to the subpoena, with priorities between indexing and further production.

locations: 401 E. Las Olas Blvd. Suite 1200 Fort Lauderdale, FL 33301
keyFacts: A grand jury subpoena was served on Boies Schiller Flexner LLP on February 5, 2019, for discovery materials in the case Giuffre v. Maxwell (15 Civ. 7433).
A sealed court order granted the law firm permission to produce materials marked 'CONFIDENTIAL' under the protective order of that specific case.
The production order explicitly does not apply to other litigation, including 'In re Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al, 17 Civ. 0616', limiting the scope of documents to be turned over.
The email chain reveals logistical coordination between attorneys and a U.S. Attorney's office regarding large-volume document production and indexing.
Sigrid McCawley mentions there are experts and key witnesses in their case materials, with some relevant only to defamation claims, indicating the complexity of the underlying litigation.
